document.docTitle: Allmonia paucicincta Harzhauser & Landau 2019, new comb.
document.masterDocTitle: Turritellidae (Gastropoda) of the Miocene Paratethys Sea with considerations about turritellid genera

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Turritellidae (Gastropoda) of the Miocene Paratethys Sea with considerations about turritellid genera

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype NHMW 1846/0010/0014, illustrated in Hörnes 1855, pl. 43, fig. 1); Eggenburgian (early Miocene ) Burgschleinitz ( Austria ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Studied material. 1 spec. NHMW 1846/0010/0014, Burgschleinitz (illustrated in Hörnes 1855, pl. 43, fig. 1, holotype of
Turritella ( Protoma ) cathedralis paucicincta Sacco, 1895
), 1 spec coll. Anton Breitenberger, 4 spec. NHMW 2018/0128/0001, NHMW 2018/0128/0002, NHMW 2018/0128/0003, NHMW 2018/0128/0004, Burgschleinitz ( Austria ), 17 spec. NHMW 1849/0013/0015, NHMW 1860/0050/0323, NHMW 1864/0001/0481, NHMW 1866/0020/00012, Eggenburg ( Austria ), 7 spec. NHMW 1851/0006/0020, NHMW 1850/0009/0050, NHMW 1860/0050/3720, NHMW 1866/0040/0038, 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0129/0001, Loibersdorf (illustrat- ed in Schaffer 1912 , pl. 53, fig. 19), 2 spec. NHMW 1850/0009/0037, Mörtersdorf ( Austria ), 2 spec. NHMW 1989/0031/0001, NHMW 1989/0031/002, Maria Dreieichen ( Austria ), 2 spec. KM , Maria Dreieichen (illustrated in Schaffer 1912 , pl. 53, figs 15, 16), 3 spec. KM , Maigen (illustrated in Schaffer 1912 , pl. 53, figs 17, 18, 21), 4 spec. NHMW 1890/0025/0015, Engelsdorf ( Austria ), 1 spec. NHMW 1860/0050/0253 Molt ( Austria ), 1 spec. NHMW 2018/0130/0001, Neuruppersdof at Laa ( Austria ), 2 spec. NHMW 2018/0131/0001, NHMW 1855/0045/0178, Steinebrunn ( Austria ), 4 spec. NHMW 1863/0015/0528, NHMW 1869/0001/0545, Forchtenau ( Austria ), 1 spec. NHMW 1863/0015/0000 Rudice ( Czech Republic ), 5 spec. NHMW 1861/0040/0117, NHMW1864/0001/5420, Hrušovany ( Czech Republic ). 1 spec. UMJG&P 1247 (Inv. No. 200323 ), Ivanji dol ( Slovenia ), illustrated in Hilber (1893 , pl. 1, fig. 1), holotype of
Turritella ( Protoma ) telleri Hilber, 1893
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Revised description. Shell large, robust, moderately slender, of at least 15–18 teleoconch whorls. Protoconch unknown. Whorl profile of first 5–6 teleoconch whorls bicarinate convex, grading into straight sided profile by 12 th to 14 th teleoconch whorl, followed by concave, telescoped whorls. First teleoconch whorls bicarinate convex with B and C spiral cords of approximately equal strength; B cord slightly below mid-whorl. Suture moderately incised. Primary spirals initially sharp becoming convex around 5 th teleoconch whorl; occasionally, secondary u spiral cord present. Bifid spiral cord A appears around 8 th to 9 th teleoconch whorl, being equal in strength to B and C cords until 9 th to 11 th teleoconch whorl. Separation into A 1 and A 2 indicated by weak incision or deep furrow. Later, A 1 and A 2 merge into a prominent, raised subsutural collar. B and C fade out within 13 th to 15 th teleoconch whorls, coinciding with transition from flat sided whorl profiles into moderately concave profiles. Abapical spiral cord d may occur close to abapical suture or may be nearly hidden by spiral cord A of subsequent whorl. Faint spiral threads cover entire shell forming delicate, cancellate pattern at cross sections with growth lines. Lateral sinus with steep angle; wide, moderately deep, simple concave with steeply prosocline adapical part and moderately opisthocyrt abapical part, passing via prominent inflection into basal sinus; adapical LS p . Last whorl with marked basal angulation coinciding with spiral cord d. Base low, markedly concave between angulation and fasciole. Very broad fasciole often with scalloping growth increments. Inner lip forming thick glossy sheet in parietal area, bordering fasciole. Outer lip thin, nearly straight sided passing via flaring convexity into moderately convex basal lip. Basal sinus deeply incised, occasionally forming short, slightly deflected canal.

Shell measurements and ratios. Complete specimens are extremely rare; largest nearly complete specimen: SL = 133.8 mm , MD = 33.1 mm . n = 8 adult specimens: mean MD 28.4 mm (σ = 3.4 mm ), AA: μ = 20.0° (σ = 2.33°), PA: μ = 14.8° (σ = 0.90°). Lateral sinus (n = 5): LS angle = 23.4° (σ = 4.3°), LS p = 1.1 (σ = 0.16), LS d = 5.8 (σ = 0.82).

Discussion. Hörnes (1855: 419) already emphasized that the Austrian shells differed from those from France , without separating them taxonomically. A comparison with shells from the early Miocene of Léognan, Bordeaux and Saucats ( France , Aquitaine Basin) in the NHMW collections supports this view. French specimens differ in having slightly higher early teleoconch whorls with a more abapical position of the B spiral cord, resulting in a higher and steeper sutural ramp. Later teleoconch whorls lack the prominent subsutural collar, resulting in a distinctly less telescoped profile. The secondary spiral cords s and t of
A. cathedralis
may attain nearly the same strength as the primary spiral cords even within the last spire whorls and the reduction of the spiral cords on the last whorls is much weaker. Moreover, the basal sinus of
A. paucicincta
is deeper. The differences in sculpture and profile were also discussed by Sacco (1895) , who introduced
paucicincta
as variation name for the Austrian shell illustrated by Hörnes (1855, pl. 43, fig. 1). Similarly, Cossmann & Peyrot (1922) stressed these differences and supported the taxonomic separation from ‘
Protoma’ cathedralis
. Herein, we treat the Paratethyan specimens as distinct species due to their geographic separation from the Italian and French populations and due to their rather constant morphology.
Allmonia paucicincta
differs from the coeval Proto-Mediterranean
A. funiculata
in its strong reduction of the spiral sculpture in late stages of growth and the markedly telescoped and adapically carinate profile. Specimens of
Allmonia funiculata
in the NHMW collections, differ also in their smaller size, more slender shells and a weakly scalloped fasciole.

Hilber (1993) considered the Austrian specimens described by Hörnes (1855) also to be different from the French
A. cathedralis
and introduced
Turritella ( Protoma ) telleri
as new name, which thus would have priority over
Protoma paucicincta Sacco 1895
. Unfortunately, the holotype is a fragment from the Badenian of Slovenia showing four prominent spiral cords, of which the adapical two are somewhat amalgamated ( Fig. 25E : SL: 44.2 mm , MD: 21.0 mm, Ivanji dol ( Slovenia ) UMJG&P 1247). This spiral sculpture differs from that of typical
A. paucicincta
. Moreover, it lacks the typical subsutural collar. It might represent an aberrant and reworked
A. paucicincta
but due to the fragmentary nature of the single available specimen, the status of
Allmonia telleri
remains unclear and we treat it as taxon inquirendum.

Schaffer (1912) introduced
Protoma cathedralis quadricincta
for spire fragments with four spiral cords, resulting from a strong separation of the A 1 and A 2 spiral cords. The specimens were collected along with typical specimens of
Protoma cathedralis paucicincta
from the same localities and layers. Even Schaffer (1912) observed transitional morphs. Consequently, we treat this taxon as subjective junior synonym of
Allmonia paucicincta
.
